=== Purchase Information === Product Title: Lady in the Water [Blu-ray] Review Date: 2010/04/28 Store: Paul Giamatti (Actor), Bryce Dallas Howard (Actor) Rated: PG-13 Format: Blu-ray Categories: Movies & TV, Blu-ray, Movies Product Description: ['Lady In The Water (BD)', ']]>'] Average Rating: 4.4 Product Details: {'Genre': 'Fantasy, Suspense, Science Fiction', 'Format': 'AC-3, Blu-ray, Closed-captioned, Color, Dolby, Dubbed, NTSC, Subtitled, Widescreen', 'Contributor': 'Freddy Rodriguez, Jared Harris, Jeffrey Wright, Bob Balaban, M. Night Shyamalan, Paul Giamatti, Sam Mercer, Sarita Choudhury, Bill Irwin, Bryce Dallas HowardFreddy Rodriguez, Jared Harris, Jeffrey Wright, Bob Balaban, M. Night Shyamalan, Paul Giamatti, Sam Mercer, Sarita Choudhury, Bill Irwin, Bryce Dallas Howard See more', 'Initial release date': '2006-12-19', 'Language': 'English (Dolby Digital 5.1), French (Dolby Digital 5.1), Spanish (Dolby Digital 5.1)', 'Aspect Ratio': '1.85:1', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'MPAA rating': 'PG-13 (Parents Strongly Cautioned)', 'Product Dimensions': '6.5 x 5.25 x 0.5 inches; 1.76 Ounces', 'Item model number': '82969', 'Director': 'M. Night Shyamalan', 'Media Format': 'AC-3, Blu-ray, Closed-captioned, Color, Dolby, Dubbed, NTSC, Subtitled, Widescreen', 'Run time': '1 hour and 49 minutes', 'Release date': 'December 19, 2006', 'Actors': 'Paul Giamatti, Bryce Dallas Howard, Bob Balaban, Jeffrey Wright, Sarita Choudhury', 'Dubbed': 'French, Spanish', 'Subtitles': 'English, French, Spanish', 'Producers': 'M. Night Shyamalan, Sam Mercer', 'Studio': 'Studio Distribution Services', 'Writers': 'M. Night Shyamalan', 'Country of Origin': 'USA', 'Number of discs': '1'} Review Text: M Knight Shamalayan made a name for himself with the movie The Sixth Sense, and for good reason. It was a great movie with a great story and a not entirely predictable "surprise" ending. I also enjoyed his follow-up film, Unbreakable (yet it wasn't too well received.) Each of his later films, however, have left me disappointed. Lady in the Water is no different. He keep trying to string insane story ideas together, only to cap them off with a "surprise" ending. A surprise ending is only a surprise if you're not expecting it! Another problem I have is how his characters always seem to just accept whatever's going on in the movie.

This film is about a water nymph that's trying to save the world from humanity. Or maybe it's to save humanity from themselves... Anyway. She shows up in the swimming pool of an apartment complex filled with very eccentric tenants. The landlord of the complex is the man who finds her, and immediately clings to this nymph. He's not quite too sure what to do with her, but conveniently there's an Asian family (Japanese, I think) that just happens to know the legend. So, to appease the elder lady of the household (who is the expert of the legend,) he goes through some rather silly exercises. Once he knows this legend, he goes to all the other tenants for help. They all immediately buy into his tale and pitch in right away. As the movie progresses, things become more and more convoluted. Eventually everyone figures out what to do, and the "surprise" happens. Seriously... I wasn't surprised in any fashion. In fact, I predicted what'd happen.

Here are the stats:

Violence/Blood/Gore: Almost none.
Boobs: None.
Likable characters: Maybe the landlord?
Plot devices that made sense: None.
People in this film that look like Jeff Goldbloom: M Knight Shamalayan.

Over all verdict: Maybe watch it on cable if you're having a hard time sleeping. Otherwise skip. Review Title: Really? Rating: 2.0 --------------------------------------------------
reference_summary:
Antichrist [Blu-ray] Willem Dafoe (Actor), Charlotte Gainsbourg (Actor), Lars von Trier (Director) & 0 more Format: Blu-ray Movies & TV, Featured Categories, Blu-ray {'Package Dimensions': '7.1 x 5.42 x 0.58 inches; 2.93 Ounces', 'Director': 'Lars von Trier', 'Media Format': 'Blu-ray', 'Actors': 'Willem Dafoe, Charlotte Gainsbourg', 'Studio': 'Zentropa Entertainment'} I streamed this one off Netflix. I've enjoyed von Trier's wor in the past, and Willem Dafoe usually provides a wonderful performance (which could be taken in other ways in this context.) The movie was amazing in the sense of being a work of art, but I don't think I could watch it a second time (though I'm tempted to buy it just to support von Trier's work.) It contains intense violence, sex and a rather bizarre story. I highly recommend it to those who enjoy a smart, artsy film and have strong stomachs. Incredibly well done, but extremely morbid. profile:
**User Profile Summary:**

- **Film Preferences:** Prefers intelligent, artsy films with strong thematic depth that provoke thought and elicit a strong emotional response. While generally supportive of unconventional narratives, the user has expressed disappointment with certain films by high-profile directors, suggesting a nuanced view on quality over reputation.
  
- **Director and Actor Affinity:** Appreciates the works of Lars von Trier and performances by Willem Dafoe, but has shown critique towards M. Night Shyamalan’s later films, indicating a selective engagement with unconventional storytelling and a desire for depth and coherence in narratives.

- **Content Tolerance:** Open to films featuring intense violence and sexual content; however, recent critiques suggest a growing expectation for such elements to be well-integrated into the storytelling.

- **Viewing Habits:** Streams films before purchasing, reflecting a cautious approach to media. However, the user’s latest review indicates a willingness to critique even previously admired filmmakers, signaling a high standard for content quality.

- **Critique Style:** Offers insightful, reflective reviews, emphasizing both artistic merit and coherence of storytelling. The user recognizes the need for plot devices to make sense and for characters to have depth, asserting that unexpected twists require proper build-up.

Overall, the user appreciates groundbreaking cinema but demonstrates critical discernment, valuing artful storytelling and a coherent narrative structure above all.
